keyTakeAways: Vice President JD Vance downplayed concerns over the fragility of the Israel-Hamas ceasefire during a news conference in Israel, stating he is optimistic but not certain the ceasefire will last.
Vance declined to set a timeline for the return of Israeli hostages or Hamas’ disarmament, emphasizing that security and humanitarian structures must be implemented in Gaza.

US officials, including Trump administration members, are privately concerned the ceasefire could collapse, especially after Hamas allegedly attacked Israeli soldiers, prompting Israeli airstrikes that killed dozens in Gaza.

The visit by Vance and key Trump administration figures (Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner) is seen as a show of force to ensure Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu remains committed to the US-negotiated ceasefire.
Israel and Hamas both accused each other of violating the ceasefire, yet both reaffirmed their commitment to it after the recent incidents.

Trump has publicly and privately questioned whether the attack on IDF soldiers was orchestrated by Hamas leaders, suggesting instead a 'rebellion' within the group, and threatened to 'eradicate' Hamas if necessary.

Trump expressed on social media that 'great allies' in the Middle East would welcome the opportunity to enter Gaza to 'straighten out' Hamas if they continue to act badly, though he currently does not believe they will act out of line.
Israeli officials are pressuring the US to demilitarize Hamas before moving into the reconstruction phase of negotiations.
The US administration’s 20-point peace plan for the region is being advanced, with current focus on ensuring the ceasefire holds and talks progress into a longer-term phase.
The US officials’ belief that the ceasefire is most threatened in the short term justifies the urgency of Vance’s visit shortly after President Trump’s own visit.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Vice President JD Vance downplayed concerns over the Israel-Hamas ceasefire during a visit to Israel, expressing optimism about its durability while refusing to set a timeline for the return of hostages or Hamas’ disarmament. This visit comes amid growing internal US concern that the ceasefire may collapse after Hamas allegedly attacked Israeli soldiers, prompting Israeli airstrikes that killed dozens in Gaza. US officials, including Trump administration figures, are worried about the deal’s fragility, especially in the short term, and see Vance’s presence as a show of force to ensure Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu remains committed. Trump himself questioned whether Hamas leaders orchestrated the attack, suggesting instead a 'rebellion' within the group, and threatened to 'eradicate' Hamas if necessary. Israeli officials are pushing for US-led demilitarization of Hamas before reconstruction talks begin. The next 30 days are seen as critical for the ceasefire to hold and for the peace process to advance toward the next phase of the 20-point peace plan.
title: Vance downplays concerns over ceasefire in visit to Israel as Trump administration officials privately worry
